entry.title: A Case Study: Mastering a Complex Rollout at a Utilities Enterprise
entry.content:
A utility company embarked on a transformative project focusing on process harmonization, establishing an ERP core as its backbone, and leveraging a merger with another enterprise to standardize processes while transitioning to S/4HANA. The rollout spanned a six-year roadmap involving more than 400 companies, 10+ countries, and over 30,000 SAP users.

The project’s complexity demanded significant attention and dedication. By its conclusion, the global team included around 10 workstreams, 25+ teams, and over 250 employees. What were the key success factors that enabled such an extensive and successful engagement?

Effective Planning

Thorough planning and preparation are fundamental to ensuring seamless cooperation and a successful go-live. In this case, the utilities company’s rollout adopted a targeted approach with clear goals. The initial rollouts for two pilot companies served as test runs to refine subsequent rollouts based on initial lessons learned.

In order to establish a Fit-to-Standard approach, a binding S/4HANA template was established, which was as closely aligned with SAP standards as possible, given the financial framework based on the analysis of the legal gaps. The template was built with the experts from all units to cover all requirements, which were later rolled out as the standard. Any exceptional requirements to enhance the template required a clear economic rationale, and local units had to justify the added value in case there were additional requirements. Remaining close to the SAP standard minimized the need for time-consuming custom developments, ensuring a rapid and efficient rollout. This approach minimized risks, controlled scope expansion, and reduced operational costs. The pilots tested the core template and helped derive valuable experience for a broader implementation.

Furthermore, the utilities company opted for a factory approach during the rollout of the project. Each factory had its tasks and responsibilities. The Test Factory, for example, ensured that E2E processes were tested and compliant with auditing standards and automation tools. The Migration Factory focused on data migrations with a specific standardized approach and tools to scale the migrations. The Cutover Factory ensured a successful and efficient go-live by leveraging cutover and steering tools, such as cutover plans and blueprints. The Communication and Change Factory’s task was to ensure the readiness of the people by informing, activating, and enabling all users with the respective knowledge transfer.

The utilities company’s “factory approach” balanced centralized governance with local execution. Central teams managed core activities like design, testing, and migration through specialized units, ensuring consistency and quality. Meanwhile, local teams addressed region-specific needs. This model fostered collaboration between central and local efforts, streamlining delivery and aligning global standards with local requirements. It enabled scalable, efficient rollouts by establishing a lean, standardized process and tool usage and ensuring transparency of all rollout steps.

Program Methodology and Governance

The customer opted for the SAP Activate methodology utilizing SAP Solution Manager (hereafter called SolMan) / Focus Build to ensure maximum transparency and run the project in an agile mode, enabling engagement of internal resources and time-efficient delivery despite COVID-19 remote work restrictions.

In the design and realization phase, the program scope was broken into three main waves, which were delivered by scrum teams, resulting in various agile sprint teams. SAP SolMan was the single source of truth, providing transparency and using scrum boards to ensure that all topics were tracked. The project also had clear guidelines and quality criteria, such as criteria for test completion and resulting documentation. The overall agile methodology, as well as SAP SolMan, resulted in the timely delivery of qualitative results by being responsive to changing requirements.

Strong program governance was another crucial factor. Initiatives of varying sizes and scopes benefit from centralized management and logical team clusters. Efficient project management methodologies and program leadership can significantly impact outcomes.

The utilities company’s governance structure included a lean finance stream supported by parallel integration and technology streams. Agile scrum teams managed deliverables dynamically, with 20 such teams driving the project forward. Over 90% of the scope was implemented within SAP standards due to robust and strict governance.

Strong governance also facilitated risk mitigation. Centrally organized meetings provided visibility to address key challenges promptly, such as restaffing roles when necessary. The utilities company and SAP collaboratively tackled issues, ensuring success through cross-team performance and motivated staff.

Structured Rollout Phases: The Core Fit2Standard Timeline

A critical enabler of the successful rollout was the structured sequencing of rollout phases within the Core Fit2Standard framework.

The utilities company adopted a phased approach that guided each rollout unit through clear steps of preparation, analysis, validation, and approval, ensuring alignment across all entities.

The process began with Local Units’ Preparation, where onboarding, the collection of local information, and team setup established the foundation. This was followed by System Demos, introducing system landscape concepts and demonstrating template processes to ensure familiarity and clarity. The Local System Analysis phase identified requirements and gaps, including necessary local adjustments. These findings then moved into Template Validation, where potential gaps were discussed, categorized, and prioritized transparently.

After validation, the Review and Approval stage involved product owners and management making final decisions on gaps and their solutions, creating an efficient and constructive core Fit2Standard process. Finally, the Upload and Planning phase ensured that requirements were transferred to the backlog, dependencies were assessed, and handovers to the template team were executed smoothly.

Key success factors for this structured rollout included proactive participation in info sessions, thorough self-studies, and the use of InfoCollectors for pre-filled data gathering. Alignment between central and local units was emphasized, with local teams responsible for ensuring that regional requirements (e.g., legal obligations) were adequately addressed. Open discussion of potential gaps, along with clear prioritization, built trust and enabled efficient resolution. This structured phasing fostered transparency, minimized surprises, and kept the program aligned with the overall project roadmap.

Collaboration and Empowerment

Collaboration across teams and the entire project ecosystem is vital for smooth implementation. Effective change management—encompassing stakeholder management, awareness building, and resistance mitigation—creates confidence and unity among affected teams.

The utilities company prioritized collaboration by adopting the philosophy “from us for us,” engaging business, IT, central, regional teams, and partners. High levels of internal resource commitment ensured everyone actively contributed to the rollout. This large-scale engagement resulted in seamless cooperation among all parties involved.

One key lesson learned was the importance of separating program steering from content steering. Trusting system and topic owners to act in the company’s best interest proved invaluable. Addressing challenges directly as they arose ensured smooth progress. Additionally, a clear escalation procedure minimized hurdles and effort, contributing to the project’s success.

Furthermore, a key element of the project was the decision and escalation path, which vested more than 80% of the decisions by the product owners. These individuals took ownership and made decisions once unresolved topics were escalated to them. Product Managers were granted the mandate to make decisions related to cross-team matters. In this way, the product owners were empowered to take decisions and remained engaged, sharing a vested interest in the project’s success.

Driving Success in Rollout Management

The utilities company’s rollout exemplifies the principles of successful SAP implementations, especially for complex solutions like S/4HANA. Key factors included:

Effective Planning: Careful preparation, piloting, and the establishment of a binding Fit-to-Standard template ensured clarity of scope and minimized unnecessary custom developments.

Program Methodology and Governance: A robust governance framework, supported by the SAP Activate methodology and SAP Solution Manager, delivered alignment, transparency, and adaptability through agile execution and strong risk management.

Structured Rollout Phases: A transparent, phased Core Fit2Standard timeline guided each rollout unit from preparation through to planning, ensuring alignment across all entities and fostering consistent execution.

Collaboration and Empowerment: Unified teams with clearly defined responsibilities, empowered product owners, and a collaborative “from us for us” philosophy fostered stakeholder engagement, accelerated decision-making, and ensured project ownership.

This case study demonstrates how disciplined planning, structured rollout phases, strong governance, and a collaborative culture can transform daunting challenges into scalable successes. For organizations embarking on similar transformative journeys, these strategies are not just recommended—they are essential.

The lessons learned extend beyond technology. They highlight the importance of structure, discipline, and unity in navigating complex rollouts. By adopting these principles, organizations can achieve their goals while maintaining operational excellence and driving meaningful change.

 

********
Co-Author: Oliver-Jens Götz

entry.title: Streamlining Data with SAP CPI Message Mapping : Sorting and Eliminating Incomplete Records
entry.content:
Introduction

In enterprise integration scenarios, managing employee data across systems is a common requirement — but raw data is often messy or incomplete.

In this blog, we’ll walk through a real-world solution in SAP Integration Suite (CPI) where we:
• Filter out invalid employee records using Message Mapping
• Sort valid employee records by EmployeeID using Groovy Script
• Deliver a clean and structured employee dataset to the target system

The goal is to streamline incoming employee data so it’s ready for consumption by downstream applications.

Business Requirement
We needed to:
• ✅ Remove employees missing EmployeeID
• ✅ Preserve only complete records with all required fields
• ✅ Sort the remaining employee records in ascending order by EmployeeID

This reflects a common need in systems like SAP SuccessFactors, SAP HCM, or third-party HR tools where employee records must be clean and ordered.

Note: 
The entire filtering and sorting of employee data could be handled using just a Groovy script. However, here I chose to use Message Mapping for filtering and Groovy only for sorting.
This approach helps demonstrate how standard tools in SAP CPI can be combined effectively — and it’s especially helpful for beginners learning both graphical and scripting options.

⚙️Tools Used
• SAP Integration Suite (CPI)
• Message Mapping – to filter out incomplete data
• Groovy Script – to sort valid data
• No external tools, APIs, or adapters needed

Better Picture

                              Sample input                                                                                    Desired Output
           


Steps to follow

  • Step 1: Filter Incomplete Records Using Message Mapping. In CPI, we first create a Message Mapping between the source and target structures (Employees → Employees).
    Goal: remove any <Employee> node where EmployeeID is missing or empty.

    Functions Used:
    • removeContext : Flattens or isolates repeated elements from their surrounding hierarchy, treating each entry as a separate context so that they can be processed individually
    • Length: return the number of characters in the given string (used here to check if EmployeeID is empty or not).
    • GreaterThan: compares two numbers and returns true if the first is greater than the second.
    • constant: provides a fixed value to compare against.
    • createIf: creates the corresponding target node only if the connected Boolean condition is true.



    EmployeeID(on source side) is mapped to Employee(on target side) to only pass records having non-empty EmployeeID.
    This is known as conditional node creation.
    Below is the mapping expression used to conditionally create nodes having non-empty EmployeeID.



    We map the rest of the fields directly one to one like shown below.




  • Step 2: Sort Valid Records Using Groovy Script

    Important Tip: Why We Use Groovy for Sorting
    🚫Message Mapping in SAP CPI cannot perform sorting operations.
    ✅It is designed for mapping and filtering data, but not for ordering or rearranging nodes.

    That’s why sorting must be handled by a Groovy script (or other scripting steps like XSLT) if required.
    If your source system can sort data (e.g., an OData service or database), it’s best to sort at the source when possible.
    But when that’s not feasible, a post-mapping script like the one we used is the recommended approach.

    Below is the groovy script used in this.



    iFlow Design
    The iFlow created looks something like this.


    Final Thoughts

    With just two steps we’ve transformed raw employee data into a clean, filtered, and sorted dataset ready for use.

    This approach can be applied to:
    • HR integrations
    • Payroll systems
    • Internal reporting systems
    • Master data consolidation flows

entry.title: Monitor CAPM service crashes using SAP BTP Alert Notification Service
entry.content:
SAP Alert Notification Service is a powerful service available on the Business Technology Platform (BTP) that helps you to monitors your applications and sends alerts when something goes wrong like an application crash so you can take immediate action.

Few things to which are required to setup beforehand:

  1. A subaccount in SAP BTP.
  2. A space created within that subaccount.
  3. Required services (capm) deployed in that space to enable monitoring.
  4. To use the Alert Notification Service, it must be subscribed within your BTP subaccount.

Now Let's create and configure Alert Notification Service

Once Create, Make sure this configuration is enabled already within the instance parameters

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


There are few terms which is very important and are explained below:

  • Events: These are the triggers specific occurrences like application crashes that the system watches for.
  • Actions: These define what should happen when a particular event is detected
  • Subscription: This is the link between events and actions. It listens for selected events and executes the configured actions when those events occur.
Flow within the Alert Notification Service:

Subscription will act as your entry point. It listens to all incoming events but only responds to the ones it’s configured for. Once a matching event is detected, it triggers the corresponding action

Configuring the Alert Notification Service:

Open the ANS dashboard, follow these steps to begin monitoring application crashes:

  1. Navigate to the "Conditions" menu.
  2. Create a new condition and set the Event Type to: app.crash
  3. This condition will help ANS identify and respond to application crash events.
Now That the Condition Is Set, Let’s Create an Action

Next, head over to the “Actions” menu from the left-hand panel in the Alert Notification Service dashboard. This is where you’ll define what should happen when your configured event like app.crash is triggered.

Select Action Type as Email and click on next

In the Actions menu, start by entering a name for your action. Then, specify the email address where you want to receive alert notifications and click on Create button

Note:  After adding your email address to the action, you’ll receive a confirmation email. Make sure to verify it before moving forward - this step is essential to start receiving alert notifications.

Now That the Action Is Set, Let’s Create a Subscription

Next, head over to the “Subscriptions” menu from the left-hand panel in the Alert Notification Service dashboard. 
Give some meaningful name and description and select your newly created action and condition as shown below:

 

 


 




 

 

 

 

 

 

Note: You might see a section called store-events in the dashboard. This was created for a different purpose, so feel free to ignore it during your setup - it’s not relevant to the current configuration.

Click Save, and just like that you’ve successfully created a subscription! Your Alert Notification Service is now ready to listen for events and take action as configured.

From now on, whenever a service crashes within the same space where your Alert Notification Service instance is set up, you’ll receive an email notification, just like the one shown below. 

 


Conclusion
Using SAP Alert Notification Service, we can now monitor services in real time. If any service crashes, we’ll receive instant alerts containing detailed information about the event.

entry.title: Mastering Total ETag in RAP , A Practical Guide.
entry.content:
In this blog I have explained the mechanism of total etag  and also differnce between  E-TAG and total etag in RAP in restful abap programming model .

Introduction :

 ETAG: the etag concept ensures that  the end user of an Odata service only changes instances with the state that is displayed on the UI .

Hence , the etag prevents changes of the BO that are not noticed by the Odata consumers .With Etag master each BO  entity can be checked independently.

TOTAL E-TAG: 

  • It enables optimistic concurrency checks durig the transition from draft to active data 
  • This total etag field on the database table is updated by the RAP runtime framework as soon as an active instance is changed  
  • Its value is compared when resuming a draft instance to ensure that the active data has not been changed after the exclusive lock has expired 

The total E-tag is used for edit-drafts, a draft that has a corresponding active instance .As soon as the exclusive lock expires and  an edit-draft is resumed , the total etag value of the draft is compared to the total ETAG value of the active instance .

The total etag is compared for all entities of BO 

Total e-tag is useful when we are changing draft data to active data .

 

why total etag? and scenario

Suppose an application is not using draft concepts ,  if it is only using e-tag then that application is also modifying the same table 

E-tag will work whenever we are loading the data in the front end , someone else changes the data  and  unknowingly  saving the data – etag will be compered 

In  order to save the data and override we use etag .

SCENARIO: 

When we start working on a draft table , we will put exclusive lock on active instance (say BOOKING ID-1)so that nobody can change the data.  

Active data base-->it will become active instance--> active instance to it will become draft instance  .

Suppose  I  have made some changes in active instance and – forgot to save it , But it will be automatically saved in draft instance – as we are working on draft 

 Chages made will be automatically saved in draft table .

As soon as we stop working – the exclusve lock will be removed from active instance (BOOKING ID-1) .

So now  the I  will come again ad start working on the draft instance which  have  Saved , again  I will put exclusive lock and make some changes in the data and save it . As soon as we save – draft instance will be converted into active instance .

What happens if we don't use total eTag? 

Suppose somebody else did some changes and those changes are not saved in draft  (the app is not using draft ) ,And we will be overwriting those changes with our changes, since we don't exactly now  whether someone eles has changed the data or not . 

Total etag will be matched automatically based on the field @Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true 

We need to match these field in behaviour definition  

The framework will update total etag field each time --> whenever we are converting draft into  active data .

Example :

1.create the table  

2.create a consumption view and provide the necessary annotation .

 3.create behaviour definition and provide total Etag and respective field.

4. create draft table .

5.create service def.

6.Create service binding.

7.OUTPUT

8.now  user 1 opens the data

9.user 2 has the same data

10.now user 1 starts editing the data 

11.suppose the user 2 trying to edit the same data--> he will get an error

13.we can see the entry in the dradft table

14.now the active draft is

15.User2 Trying to edit active draft with different value->getting error->No data found 

16.Now user2 trying to edit  with Same value->updated 

 

So total etag comes into picture !!

Conclusion:

<< Whenever we wil save the data  from active to draft instance – before saving I will compare total e-tag  value  

If it matches --> I shall save the data  

If it does not match --> i shall not save 

Whenever we change the  active data --> total etag changes each time . If nobody changes the data  ---> total etag will be matched  

If somebody changes the data--> total  etag will not be matched , we need to discrad the current draft and  we need to load the current data  

NOTE: whenever we change the draft data into active data we need total etag

 

thank you !

- Pradeep Ishwar Devadiga

entry.title: Additional Document Splitting Characteristics for Controlling
entry.content:
Document splitting in FI documents has long been a topic of discussion, mainly due to its impact on reporting. The approach depends on the specific business scenarios. For example, if reporting is required by ‘Profit Center,’ then every line item in the FI document must reflect the corresponding Profit Center.

The document splitting characteristics for General Ledger accounting can be maintained at the following path:
Finance → Accounting and Financial Close → General Ledger Accounting → Business Transaction → Document Splitting → Document Splitting Characteristics for General Ledger Accounting

This configuration ensures that the document balances to zero at the splitting characteristic level—in this case, the Profit Center. For example:

Cr Vendor                 1000   EUR     PC100

Dr Expense Account 1000   EUR     PC100

Similarly:

Cr Vendor1               1000   EUR     PC100

Cr Vendor2               1000   EUR     PC200

Dr Expense Account 1000   EUR     PC100

Dr Expense Account 1000   EUR     PC200

In both scenarios, although the expense account remains the same, the amounts in the second case are distributed according to the Profit Center assigned to each vendor line item.

These are common scenarios, but there are also additional Document Splitting Characteristics designed for Controlling and for subsequent processes.

For instance, if the business requires CO reporting at the ‘Internal Order’ or ‘WBS Element’ level and wants each cost element to be posted to the respective IO or WBS, additional document splitting characteristics can be maintained for Controlling.

This is configured at:
Finance → Accounting and Financial Close → General Ledger Accounting → Business Transaction → Document Splitting → Document Splitting Characteristics for Controlling

Example:
The system can split line items in processes such as:

  • Clearing of Vendor/Customer Items
    • Cash Discount Paid
    • Cash Discount Received
    • Lost Cash Discount
  • Clearing Open Items
    • Realized Exchange Rate Differences
  • Foreign Currency Valuation for Open Items
    • Expenses/Profit from Foreign Currency Valuation
  • Flat-rate Individual Value Adjustment for Vendor/Customer Items
    • Expenses/Profit from Individual Value Adjustment

For example, in clearing open items:
A vendor invoice inherits an Internal Order (IO) from its Purchase Order (PO).

When the vendor payment is processed, the system automatically assigns this IO number to the realized gain account (cost element) in the payment document.

At the time of posting the invoice, the document is split on vendor line items based on the Profit Center (the document splitting characteristic at the GL level). When posting vendor payments, the line item for the realized gain is further split based on the inherited cost object—i.e., the Internal Order from the invoice.

entry.title: Sizing Your Success: A Guide to SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
From my perspective, effective sizing is one of the most underestimated yet critical aspects of any SAP transformation. While SAP offers a standardized and well-defined architecture, every customer’s landscape, data footprint, and performance expectations are unique. This makes it essential for customers and their implementation partners to take ownership of sizing, validation, and optimization activities.

For SAP customers, partners, and technical teams navigating the shift to SAP S/4HANA and other solutions within SAP Cloud ERP Private, accurate system sizing is paramount. While SAP provides a globally consistent, standardized architecture, the responsibility for executing and validating sizing activities rests squarely with the customer and their implementation partners.

Ultimately, accurate sizing isn’t just a technical exercise; it’s a strategic enabler for stability, scalability, and long-term cost efficiency.

This guide demystifies SAP sizing, focusing on the core concepts, benefits, and practical methods within the SAP Cloud ERP Private landscape.

What is SAP Cloud ERP Private?

SAP Cloud ERP Private is a cloud-based offering that marries the control of an on-premise system with the agility and efficiency of the cloud. It guides customers toward a clean core through standardized processes and modern extensibility via SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), and in-app extensibility tools.

I think the biggest advantage of running SAP on certified cloud infrastructure that SAP Cloud ERP Private oferring adheres to is how it simplifies everything — security, compliance, and support are all built in. It lets IT teams spend less time keeping the lights on and more time driving innovation. The key, though, is being ready to fully embrace the cloud mindset to get the most out of it.

For more information please refer to Understanding the Distinct Scope of SAP Cloud ERP Private.

General SAP Sizing Overview

SAP sizing is the process of precisely determining the required hardware resources such as CPU, memory, storage, and network capacity to effectively support an SAP system based on specific business needs. It’s a blend of science, utilizing tools and calculations, and expert judgment to account for the unique context of each implementation.

Key aspects of sizing include:

  • Translating Business Requirements: Starting with user counts, transaction volumes, data growth, and performance expectations.
  • Hardware Determination: Calculating the required compute, memory, and storage.
  • Iterative Process: Sizing isn't a one-time event. It must be revisited as the business and technology evolve. This is because sizing relies on assumptions and approximations about future usage, and it must balance optimal performance with cost management.
  • Data Quality is Critical: The accuracy of the sizing results is heavily dependent on the quality of the validated usage data and sizing assumptions provided by customers and partners.

SAP Cloud ERP Private Sizing Strategy

Sizing for SAP Cloud ERP Private is a vital step to ensure your infrastructure efficiently supports your SAP workloads. SAP offers two primary models:

  1. Standard Sizing: A simplified, consumption-based model using predefined T-shirt size service bundles (e.g., XXS to 4XL), which provides a baseline scope with a minimal sizing effort.
  2. Tailored Sizing: A more granular, customized approach for complex landscapes, offering greater flexibility based on detailed requirements.

Key Sizing Steps

A structured approach to sizing includes:

  • Define the Scope: Identify the SAP applications (e.g., SAP S/4HANA, SAP BW/4HANA) and specific modules, determine transaction workloads, and define usage (e.g., Production, QA).
  • Collect Baseline Data: Use tools like the SAP Quick Sizer for new systems or EarlyWatch Reports and historical data (ST03N / ST06) for existing ones. For migrations, the SAP Readiness Check is essential.
  • Use SAP Sizing Tools: Leverage tools like Quick Sizer (greenfield) or specific sizing reports like /SDF/HDB_SIZING (brownfield) to get technical resource estimates.
  • Incorporate Growth & Buffer: Always plan for projected growth (3–5 years) and add a buffer (typically 10–25%) for peak loads and future needs.
  • Validate with Experts: Review and validate sizing with SAP experts, potentially via a "Size to Scale" engagement through SAP Premium Engagement.

Standard Sizing: The T-Shirt Model

The Standard approach maps your business needs to a predefined, T-shirt-sized model.

Full User Equivalent (FUE)

The starting point for Standard sizing is calculating the Full User Equivalent (FUE). An FUE reflects the average workload of a typical user, with different user types weighted accordingly:

User Type

FUE Weight

Developer Access

0.50

Advanced Use

1

Core Use

5

Self-Service Use

30

The final FUE count determines the required hardware package.

Example Sizing Tiers (SAP S/4HANA Illustration)*

T-Shirt Size

FUE Range

Production DB RAM (Example)

XXS

60 to 135

256 GB

XS

136 to 550

256 GB

S

551 to 1,000

512 GB

L

2,001 to 4,000

2,048 GB

*This for illustration only. Always refer to the SAP Service Description Guide for the latest metrics.

Strategies in Deployment Models

Model

Sizing Method

Primary Tool(s)

Key Action

Greenfield (new implementation)

Use projected user and transaction volumes

SAP Quick Sizer (SAP HANA-based)

The tool outputs can then mapped to FUE and a corresponding T-shirt size.

Brownfield (system conversion)

Analyze historical data and current system usage

/SDF/HDB_SIZING report (SAP Note 1872170)

Perform data archiving and cleanup first, then run the report to estimate SAP HANA memory and map to the closest T-shirt size.

Refer to the Key Resources section for tools and reports that will help you identify the right option for your scope.

Tailored Sizing: Customization for Complexity

The Tailored Option provides granular control and customized hardware specifications. This model combines standard tools with deep expert analysis, allowing more precise control over application server sizing and high-availability (HA)/disaster-recovery (DR) configurations.

Tailored Sizing Approaches

Model

Sizing Method

Primary Tool(s)

Key Action

Greenfield

Based on business assumptions and projected volumes

SAP Quick Sizer (SAP HANA-based)

Generates hardware-independent recommendations (SAPS, memory, disk).

Brownfield

Based on analysis of historical data and system usage

/SDF/HDB_SIZING report, SAP Readiness Check, EWA

Housekeeping is critical. Report output is refined by an SAP expert to account for custom code and specific usage.

In a tailored environment, the strategy shifts to "right-sizing" for current needs. This means leveraging the cloud’s elasticity to scale up or down instead of provisioning for multi-year growth upfront, which is the case for traditional on-premise models.

Refer to the Key Resources section for tools and reports that will help you identify the right option for your scope.

“Size to Scale” and Technical Assessment

The SAP Cloud ERP Private Technical Assessment is a mandatory, comprehensive evaluation designed to analyze and document the technical requirements, architecture, and sizing needs.

SAP Expert Sizing Engagement

For complex, large, or unusual landscapes, engaging an SAP expert is highly recommended. The "Size to Scale" is the expert sizing service from SAP offered via SAP Premium Engagements (MaxAttention or ActiveAttention). It provides a deep-dive, tailored sizing service.

When is "Size to Scale" required?

SAP proactively escalates an implementation for expert review if:

  • Initial analysis indicates a SAP HANA DB Requirement > 4 TiB.
  • A large amount of custom code is being migrated.
  • There are plans to consolidate multiple ERP solutions or significant new functionality (e.g., embedded EWM/TM).

SAP Sizing & Technical Assessment Engagement Flow

The sizing process is a multi-step flow involving different teams:

  1. Initiation & Scoping: Define objectives and scope with Customer, SAP Account Executives, and SAP Cloud Architecture & Advisory (CAA).
  2. Data Collection & Pre-Assessment: Customer and partner run sizing reports (e.g., /SDF/HDB_SIZING, SAP Readiness Check) and collect historical performance data.
  3. Sizing Analysis: The SAP CAA team analyzes data, maps it to infrastructure (T-shirt or tailored specs), and applies the necessary growth buffer.
  4. Technical Assessment Review & Validation: Finalized sizing assumptions are reviewed, aligned on HA/DR/network, documented in the Technical Assessment Report, and signed off by the customer.
  5. Handover to Delivery: The infrastructure is provisioned as per the agreed specifications.

Monitoring and Reporting in Cloud ERP, Private

After provisioning, continuous monitoring is key to validating the sizing and ensuring performance. This is managed through core services provided as part of the SAP Cloud ERP Private offering:

  • Capacity Management: This ongoing process ensures the environment meets performance and availability requirements by monitoring utilization, forecasting demand, and dynamically adjusting resource allocation.
  • Problem Management: This function identifies, analyzes, and resolves capacity and performance issues. It links directly back to sizing by investigating if initial assumptions were inaccurate and recommending a necessary resizing or optimization.
  • Performance Benchmarking (Enhanced Operations Services for Large Enterprises – EOS LE): A jointly defined service that measures selected business transactions over time, helping to identify performance trends and proactively mitigate future issues. 

    For more information on EOS LE please refer to SAP Cloud ERP, Private Service Description site.

By diligently performing and validating your sizing assumptions, your organization can ensure that your SAP S/4HANA journey in SAP Cloud ERP Private is built on a foundation of optimal performance, scalability, and cost efficiency.

Greenfield vs. Brownfield: Sizing Strategies for SAP S/4HANA Success

When moving to SAP S/4HANA, especially within the SAP Cloud ERP Private environment, the path you choose dictates your sizing strategy. Do you start fresh (greenfield) or convert an existing system (brownfield)?

While both methods rely on core SAP sizing tools, the inputs, assumptions, and required infrastructure for CPU, RAM, and storage diverge significantly. Understanding these differences is crucial for accurate provisioning and avoiding costly over- or under-sizing.

Sizing Approaches: Greenfield vs. Brownfield at a Glance

Aspect

Greenfield Sizing

Brownfield Sizing

Data Volume

New system, usually reduced data footprint (selective migration)

Full data migration — larger existing database size (full history)

Sizing Approach

Based on projected business requirements (users, transactions, volumes)

Based on existing system usage and historical performance metrics

Primary Tools

SAP Quick Sizer, business blueprints

SAP HANA sizing reports (e.g., /SDF/HDB_SIZING)

Custom Code

Limited or redesigned; minimal impact on sizing

Custom code retained; requires analysis (Custom Code Analyzer) as it may increase RAM/CPU requirements

Sizing Buffer

Add buffer for uncertainties in new processes (e.g., 20–30%)

Add buffer for custom code, transition load, and compatibility layers (e.g., 15%)


Greenfield Sizing: Building from the Blueprint

Use Case: A new SAP S/4HANA system deployment, often involving redefined, standardized business processes and a selective data migration.

Key Considerations:

  • Reliance on SAP Quick Sizer: Since no historical data exists, sizing is purely business-driven. You input future metrics like the number of users by type, sales order volumes, and financial transaction counts. The Quick Sizer outputs estimates for SAP HANA memory, CPU cores, and disk sizes.
  • Reduced Data Footprint: Greenfield often means selective data migration (e.g., only the last 2–3 years of transactional history). This results in a smaller initial database, lower storage requirements, and reduced initial RAM needs.
  • Cleaner Architecture: With fewer customizations and a focus on standard SAP S/4HANA processes, sizing for application performance is more predictable.
  • Add a Growth Buffer: As with any new implementation, add a significant buffer (typically ~20–30%) to account for future data growth, unforeseen business process changes, or new functionality adoption.

Brownfield Sizing: Converting the Past to the Future

Use Case: Converting an existing SAP ECC or SAP S/4HANA system to the private cloud, retaining existing processes and full data history.

Key Considerations:

  • Historical Data Analysis is Key: Sizing is usage-based. You must analyze the current system's historical performance to get an accurate estimate.
    • Workload Analysis: Use ST03N (workload analysis) and ST06 (system resources) data, and EarlyWatch Reports to understand CPU and memory utilization patterns.
    • Data Archiving is Best Practice: To optimize your sizing, archive and clean up unnecessary data before running the sizing reports.
  • The Crucial Sizing Report: The primary tool is the SAP HANA Sizing Report (/SDF/HDB_SIZING), detailed in SAP Note 1872170. This report runs on your existing system to analyze current database size, compression factors, and transaction volumes, providing a precise estimate of the required SAP HANA memory.
  • Accounting for Custom Code: Custom programs and reports (often numerous in an SAP ECC system) require assessment. The Custom Code Analyzer helps evaluate their impact, as unoptimized custom code can significantly increase required CPU and RAM.
  • Include Conversion Load: Be aware that the migration itself requires a temporary sizing uplift for staging, code remediation, and data transformation activities.

Example Sizing Comparison Snapshot

Metric

Greenfield

Brownfield

Initial DB Size

∼500 GB (selected)

1.5 TB (full)

SAP HANA Memory Estimate

∼256 GB

∼768 GB

CPU Cores

∼16–20 cores

∼36–40 cores

 

Key Recommendations and Next Steps

Sizing is a collective responsibility. While SAP and its certified partners provide the tools and expertise, customers must provide validated data and usage assumptions.

Always Validate:

  • Consult Experts: Always validate your sizing results—especially for complex brownfield conversions—with SAP CAA or a "Size to Scale" expert engagement through SAP Premium Engagement.
  • Compare Results: If you are unsure, run both the Quick Sizer (for a clean slate estimate) and the sizing reports (for historical usage) and compare the outcomes.
  • Documentation is Key: All sizing assumptions, data sources, and final resource estimates must be formally documented in the Technical Assessment Report as part of your SAP Cloud ERP Private onboarding.

Essential Resources:

Tool / Report

Use Case

SAP Note / Link

SAP Quick Sizer

Greenfield sizing (Business-driven)

SAP Sizing Resource

/SDF/HDB_SIZING

Brownfield, SAP ECC HANA Sizing

SAP Note 1872170

SAP Readiness Check

Brownfield Conversion Assessment

SAP Note 2758146

Custom Code Analyzer

Brownfield Code Impact Review

SAP Note 2290622

SAP Note 2296290

SAP BW/4HANA Sizing Report

SAP Note 2296290

By paying close attention to these greenfield and brownfield distinctions, you ensure your SAP S/4HANA landscape in SAP Cloud ERP Private is built on the right foundation for performance and scalability from day one.

Key Resources for SAP Sizing & Technical Readiness

Proper sizing and technical readiness are critical when planning, deploying, or migrating SAP solutions. Whether moving to SAP S/4HANA, SAP BW/4HANA, SAP Datasphere, or deploying on cloud platforms, the right references ensure smooth execution.

SAP Sizing Resources

  • SAP Sizing toolset
  • SAP Service Description Guide – scope of SAP services
  • SAP Note 1872170 – ABAP on SAP HANA sizing (SAP S/4HANA, Suite on SAP HANA)
  • SAP Note 2296290 – SAP BW/4HANA sizing
  • SAP Note 3599138 – SAP Datasphere sizing for non-BW systems

SAP Readiness Check

A self-service tool for migration planning and risk identification.

  • SAP Readiness Check Landing Page (SAP Support Launchpad)
  • SAP Note 2758146 – SAP S/4HANA Readiness Check
  • SAP Note 3112362 – Latest information for Readiness Check
  • SAP Note 2290622 – Custom Code Analysis

Hyperscaler References

Microsoft Azure

  • M-Series VMs
  • SAP Note 1928533 – SAP Applications on Microsoft Azure: Supported Products and VM Types

Google Cloud (GCP)

  • Certified VM Types
  • SAP Note 2456432 – SAP Applications on Google Cloud: Supported Products and Machine Types

Amazon Web Services (AWS)

  • EC2 Instance Types
  • SAP Note 1656099 – SAP Applications on AWS: Supported DB/OS and EC2 Products

Certified SAP HANA Hardware

  • SAP Certified Hardware Directory

Ultimately, using these official SAP and cloud provider resources helps ensure your landscape is right-sized, supported, and future-ready.
